questions.text: A person diagnosed with anogenital warts has a high risk of cancer. Which strain of HPV can cause a high risk of cancer? DERMATOLOGY
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HPV 18 The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Perianal/ Anogenital warts. Infections with HPV 16 and 18 are associated with a high risk of cancer out of which risk is more with HPV18> 16. Warts: Cause: HPV infection- DNA virus Warts can be classified as Anogenital warts: Cause: Low-risk HPV- 6,11; High risk- 16,18 Characteristics: Large malodorous masses which may form on vulvar and perianal skin Some lesions are flat, though more conspicuous than plane warts elsewhere, generally on non-mucosal surfaces such as the penile shaft, pubic skin, perianal skin and groins HPE: Shows extreme acanthosis and papillomatosis Horny layer is parakeratotic Treatment of HPV infection: Topical lactic acid, salicylic acid Electrocautery Cryotherapy

Highyeild:

Condyloma accuminata condyloma lata caused by HPV 6>11 Treponema pallidum- Secondary syphilis Easily bleeds on touch No bleeding Rough,verrucous, dry flat and moist soft, pedunculated induration, sessile Dark ground examination: Negative positive Treatment: Podophyllum resin 25% in alcohol Penicillin

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. HPV 11: Anogenital warts , Low grade risk of intraepithelial neoplasms Option C. HPV 6: Anogenital warts , Low grade risk of intraepithelial neoplasms Option D. HPV 5: Epidermodysplasia verruciformis

questions.text: A patient came with the nail findings as shown below along with irregular pitting, oil drop sign, and Subungual hyperkeratosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Psoriasis The given clinical image with nail findings of irregular pitting, oil drop sign and subungual hyperkeratosis is suggestive of Psoriasis . Nail findings in psoriasis - Psoriasis may affect any part of the nail unit, including the nail matrix, nail bed, and hyponychium. Nail matrix disease presents with pits, ridges and grooves of the nail plate. Nail pitting Deep, coarse, irregular depressions in the nail plate. Oil spots or salmon patches (Pathognomic) Translucid and discolored red–yellow patches located on the nail plate Onycholysis Separation of the nail plate from nail bed Subungual hyperkeratosis Raising the nail plate off the nail bed as a result of deposition of keratinocytes Longitudinal ridging Linear lines over the nail plates Splinter hemorrhages Small, linear structures, 2–3 mm long, at the distal end of nail plate

Highyeild:

Psoriasis It is a chronic, T-cell mediated , inflammatory skin disease presenting with different phenotypes due to the interplay of genetics, environmental, and immunological factors. Normal epidermal transit time is 28 days. In Psoriasis, transit time is around 3 to 5 days leading to hyperproliferation of the epidermis. Pathophysiology: T cell-mediated chronic infection.Association of gene PSORS1-9.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B .Onychomycosis: Fungal nail infections are common infections of the fingernails or toenails that can cause the nail to become discolored, thick, and more likely to crack and break. Option C .Lichen Planus: It is a condition that can cause swelling and irritation in the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes. On the skin, lichen planus usually appears as purplish, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks. Option D. Alopecia areata: It is an autoimmune disorder that usually results in unpredictable, patchy hair loss. The nail had regular pitting, unlike psoriasis.

questions.text: A female patient presented with hair loss and thinning for 1 month as seen in the image. History of covid-19 infection 8 weeks ago. The condition is most likely due to?

options.label: B
options.text: Male Pattern Hair Loss in Female

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Telogen Effluvium The given clinical history is suggestive of Telogen effluvium. A common cause of temporary hair loss due to excessive shedding of resting hair( Telogen hair) after a major stress. Pathogenesis: The new hair coming up through the scalp and pushes out the resting club hairs. So, paradoxically, this type of hair loss is a sign of hair regrowth. Can occur in an age group and both sexes Feature: Non-scarring, diffuse hair loss No clinical or histological evidence of inflammation Can affect up to 50% of scalp hair Chronic Telogen effluvium usually accompanies chronic illness <

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Male patterned hair loss: Usually have recession of the frontal temporal hairline, leading to bald patches on the vertex scalp. Option C. Trichotillomania: It is a disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to remove or pull one's own hair, which results in alopecia Option D. Fungal infection: It is called tinea capitis which can present as a grey patch or black dot.

questions.text: A patient undergoing treatment of borderline tuberculoid leprosy presents with lesions on the forehead, nose and extending to bilateral cheeks. What is the nerve affected in this Patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trigeminal Nerve Here, the lesions involve both cheeks and facial area. The sensory supply of the face is given by the Trigeminal nerve.

Highyeild:

Features of nerve involvement in Leprosy: Enlarged, thickened nerves Sensory component is affected first . (pain and temperature> position and vibration ) Autonomic dysfunction is always present in severe nerve damage . Motor nerve involvement: Ulnar = Peroneal > Median Preserved tendon reflexes Routinely palpated nerves "of predilection" in leprosy: Great auricular nerve Ulnar nerve Radial cutaneous nerve Median nerve Lateral popliteal nerve Posterior tibial nerve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .Trochlear nerve: supplies the superior oblique muscle of the eyeball. Option B. Abducens nerve: supplies the lateral rectus muscle of the eyeball and thus can be ruled out. Option C . Ulnar nerve: supplies the three hypothenar muscles, the two medial lumbricals, the seven interossei, the adductor pollicis, and the deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis.
